text: Aloha everyone. I'm Breck, a researcher at the UH Cancer Center Honolulu. My main communities these days are HN, Lobsters, /r/programminglanguages/, and SUS. I work on Tree Notation and am creating the Tree Notation Lab here. Our theory is there is a natural notation sitting between binary notation and higher level languages that has been overlooked and it could be a silver bullet. We call it Tree Notation and it's very promising (though we might have some details wrong---always looking for help). To be thorough, we build the largest database of programming and computer languages in the world with over 10K languages and over 1K columns (in the process of open sourcing it!). The first key applications we are working on is for a new data science language and studio for cancer/bioinformatics researchers, and a new grammar for electronic medical records. We are also helping over 30 companies now experiment with new languages in domains from tax returns to logic languages to visual ides and new languages for deep learning. DC referred me to this community and it looks very cool! I have never gotten into the Slack habit, so I apologize for noob mistakes.

text: I'm curious about Tree Notation. How does it compare to something like, say, LLVM IR?

elements.text: I'm curious about Tree Notation. How does it compare to something like, say, LLVM IR?

text: You could make a Tree Language that compiles to LLVM IR

elements.text: You could make a Tree Language that compiles to LLVM IR

text: Tree Notation is a dumb, error-less notation (like binary), that is just a slight step above binary, giving you trees, abstraction and scopes

elements.text: Tree Notation is a dumb, error-less notation (like binary), that is just a slight step above binary, giving you trees, abstraction and scopes

text: Although dead simple, it has very interesting properties. It makes programs isomorphic to spreadsheets (instead of function arguments, for example, we have cells fixed in geometry)

elements.text: Although dead simple, it has very interesting properties. It makes programs isomorphic to spreadsheets (instead of function arguments, for example, we have cells fixed in geometry)

text: It plays nicely with git -- all changes are semantic and nodes are line based

elements.text: It plays nicely with git -- all changes are semantic and nodes are line based

text: I could ramble on all day about it

text: But hopefully soon the tooling, demos, and docs will do a better job of explaining it than I can....(I've found it's actually often more helpful if someone else explains it to people, as I've been working on it for 7 years I forget what it's like to see it with fresh eyes)

text: If every tree is valid, and no syntax errors can happen, then what is to prevent a programmer from making logical mistakes? Isn't the whole progression of computer languages been one of a steady march towards having the computer do more of the detail work so as to reduce the chance for human error, which is the main thing we fight in computers. Machines are incredibly fast and have large storage now, the only thing limiting us is our ability to make reliable programs. Sorry, but the tree notation seems formless and thus not in the direction of progress. Change  my mind...

text: Hi <@UEQ6M68H0>. There are no errors at the Tree Notation level, just as there is no such thing as an error in binary notation. However, there are errors at the "Tree Language" level. If you try some of the sample languages in the designer app (you might need a stiff drink--the app is still early stages), you can make an error and see how because Tree Languages are so much easier to parse since the AST == Source Code and there's no visible syntax characters, we can create a whole new generation of more intelligent editing experiences. Right now, depending on the type of error, we are able to suggest autocorrections immediately. I 100% agree with you in the importance of reliability. I expect we see a reduction in software defects of 10x+ in Tree Projects vs current projects across the industry in a few years. Once you have put a software project in the minimal Tree form, it's done and timeless. The parts of our software stack that have the fewest bugs are all in Tree Languages now.

elements.text: Hi

If you try some of the sample languages in the designer app (you might need a stiff drink--the app is still early stages), you can make an error and see how because Tree Languages are so much easier to parse since the AST == Source Code and there's no visible syntax characters, we can create a whole new generation of more intelligent editing experiences. Right now, depending on the type of error, we are able to suggest autocorrections immediately. I 100% agree with you in the importance of reliability. I expect we see a reduction in software defects of 10x+ in Tree Projects vs current projects across the industry in a few years. Once you have put a software project in the minimal Tree form, it's done and timeless. The parts of our software stack that have the fewest bugs are all in Tree Languages now.

text: Aloha <@UCUSW7WVD> ! So good to hear from you again. Your advice was some of the best I got back in the day. I kind of learned I needed to shut up and "learn how to research properly", as one person so simply put it. So did just that for a while. How are things in the Arc world? I may go take a stroll on the good ol' boards and see what's been happening lately.

text: <@UCUSW7WVD> SUS is StartupSchool. Most fun thing I've done in a while -- I highly recommend it, even if you are not doing a startup (I am not). DC are just the initials of the guy who told me to check out this forum.

text: Aloha <@UMPQ9A65N>! I love VS Code, and almost always have it open (though I have to admit, Sublime Text is still my primary editor). Christof Marti is a good friend and former coworker (he's always trying to find out why I'm still on Sublime--I thought I was gonna completely switch over by now but then sublime released the new version, as well as sublime merge, and now tabnine is awesome). Have you seen <https://tabnine.com/>? It's very interesting. For languages without LSP yet, but's been a life saver.

attachments.text: TabNine is the all-language autocompleter. We use deep learning to help you write code faster.

text: Hi <@UMPQ9A65N> Sounds cool! I've made syntax highlighters for Sublime (which is basically Textmate's format in YAML) and it has been really painful experience. Mainly because my languages are context sensitive. I've also made them in CodeMirror, and it's a total breeze. All I need is access to the document, and can easily spit out hightlight scopes for any position programmatically if I can run my own parser code. Will the new thing you are working on allow me to run my own JS code to return highlights? It sounds like it, but I just want to confirm

text: <@UMVFWPZ36> and Kartik, I’m very interested in what you learned about “how to research properly”, though it’s a tangent off a tangent now. I feel like that might be the most important thing I didn’t learn by not getting a PhD.

elements.text: and Kartik, I’m very interested in what you learned about “how to research properly”, though it’s a tangent off a tangent now. I feel like that might be the most important thing I didn’t learn by not getting a PhD.

text: <@UD3AK9JRF> I don't have a phd either. I was able to get a job at UHCC because they needed people who knew cloud computing and machine learning. I didn't know biology but the team knows that (I've learned a lot but still far from an expert) and it's been a great partnership. I've worked alongside lots of bioinformaticians, researchers, and clinicians analyzing data and writing code ; been coauthor on 10 or so peer reviewed papers now (a few still in the review process) whereas before I couldn't define "peer review" ; I've been on the reviewer side of the table; have gone to the academic conferences and talks; gotten to know lots of academics and got some great mentors. So I think I at least now "know how to research properly" (thought I reserve my right to do it in a slightly different way :wink: ) which has been helpful. I also just doubled down heavily on getting better at building huge curated datasets, because data trumps brains :slightly_smiling_face:.

text: Well Breck, how about taking one or more of the examples from my github repository of the tiny 500 -1000 word programs, and show how they might be represented in your tree notation. In the case of the clock, the Beads notation form is already within spitting distance of the minimum possible length program, and i don't believe that merely putting things into AST form makes the program more understandable. The comments are gone in tree form as your examples in your paper show, so isn't this more like LISP without parentheses? I agree that editing in the AST has some advantages in terms of prediction, but creation of new content is more mysterious to me. This is why some people are heading towards fill-in-the-blanks type of approaches, so you have support for entering the fields you need, and the keywords are put in the right place. I think if you took a larger program like chess it might obscure the meaning of the code to put it into a deeply nested tree. Deep nesting is the enemy of comprehension, as LISP proved 50 years ago.

The comments are gone in tree form as your examples in your paper show, so isn't this more like LISP without parentheses? I agree that editing in the AST has some advantages in terms of prediction, but creation of new content is more mysterious to me. This is why some people are heading towards fill-in-the-blanks type of approaches, so you have support for entering the fields you need, and the keywords are put in the right place. I think if you took a larger program like chess it might obscure the meaning of the code to put it into a deeply nested tree. Deep nesting is the enemy of comprehension, as LISP proved 50 years ago.

text:
From <https://arxiv.org/pdf/1703.01192.pdf>:

> notations such as XML, JSON, and Racket can encode multilingual programs by complecting language blocks. For example, the JSON program below requires extra  nodes to encode Python:
> ```
> {"source": [
>   "import <http://hn.np|hn.np> as lz\n",
>   "print(\"aaronsw pdm ah as mo gb 28-3\")"
>   ]
> }
> ```
>
> With TN, the Python code requires no complecting:
> ```
> source
>  import <http://hn.np|hn.np> as lz
>  print("aaronsw pdm ah as mo gb 28-3")
> ```

It's not clear to me how the newline after `lz` does double-duty for both the newline inside the string and the comma (array separator) outside the string.

elements.text: From
notations such as XML, JSON, and Racket can encode multilingual programs by complecting language blocks. For example, the JSON program below requires extra  nodes to encode Python:

> {"source": [
>   "import
hn.np

as lz\n",
>   "print(\"aaronsw pdm ah as mo gb 28-3\")"
>   ]
> }
>
With TN, the Python code requires no complecting:

> source
>  import
hn.np

as lz
>  print("aaronsw pdm ah as mo gb 28-3")
>
It's not clear to me how the newline after
lz
does double-duty for both the newline inside the string and the comma (array separator) outside the string.
